title: About
text: Hi! My name is Alina and I am a student in COMM 4190 - Talking with AI: Computational and Communication Approaches! This blog is about my explorations using LLMâ€™s :) Iâ€™m a senior studying Biochemistry and minoring in Data Science & Analytics!

title: Can LLMs Walk Me Through the Wordle?
text:
Iâ€™ve already tested Chat-GPT5 on brain teaser puzzles. How well does it do on Wordle?
Task: I am going to ask ChatGPT5 to begin a Wordle by giving me a 5 letter word. I am not going to tell the LLM that I will be inputting it into Wordle, so it doesnâ€™t give me an â€œoptimalâ€ word. Then I will describe (in words) the result and ask ChatGPT5 to give me another word as the next prompt. I will continue until the LLM fails or succeeds. Letâ€™s go!

First 5-letter word choice: crisp
Reprompt:

the letter c is in the correct place, every other letter is not present in the word. try again with another 5 letter word.

Next guess: cloak
Reprompt:

the c is still correct. the o is in the word but doesnâ€™t appear at that location. every other letter is not in the word. try again

Next guess: count
Reprompt:

c and o are in the right place. n appears in the word but not that location. every other letter is not present. try again

Next guess: coven

Correct!!



Letâ€™s compare it to Wordle Bot - NYTâ€™s Wordle Analyzer
Letâ€™s go step by step:

Crisp - Rated 93 skill; 92 words remaining; on average, Wordle Bot can solve it in 3.6 steps with this word
Cloak - Rated 72 skill; 18 words left, Alone would have been a better word
Count - Rated 74 skill; 4 words left, Month would have been a better word
Coven - Rated 67 skill, correct word




My Reflection
Although ChatGPT may not have the best reputation when it comes to solving word puzzles, so far, it seems to be able to solve Wordle! One thing that I wanted to note is that the LLM took a bit longer for each successive round. From round 1 to round 2, it thought for a â€œfew secondsâ€. From round 2 to round 3, it thought for 9 seconds. THen, from round 3 to round 4, it thought for 11 seconds. I am assuming it was going through potential options to narrow down ones that fit the criteria as the criteria became more and more specific.
ChatGPT didnâ€™t have bad guesses, but they still werenâ€™t optimal. As shown by Wordle Bot, each word after the first was rate a skill number less than 80. However, I think it did a good job in removing words. This may have also been a fault of my own prompts because I worded it in a way that hinted that guesses had the keep the correct letters already guessed. If this was not the case, perhaps the LLM may have guessed the â€˜optimalâ€™ word, as determined by Wordle Bot.

text: I am going to ask ChatGPT (chatgpt-4o-latest) how to play an instrument. To test this first, Iâ€™ll be asking the LLM to teach me about an instrument I already know how the play, the ukulele. In Part 2, Iâ€™ll try to use it to learn to play an instrument Iâ€™ve never even touched before!

title: How Well Can An LLM Teach Me To Play An Instrument: Part 1
text: I am going to ask ChatGPT (chatgpt-4o-latest) how to play an instrument. To test this first, Iâ€™ll be asking the LLM to teach me about an instrument I already know how the play, the ukulele. In Part 2, Iâ€™ll try to use it to learn to play an instrument Iâ€™ve never even touched before!

title: How Well Can An LLM Teach Me To Play An Instrument: Part 1
text:
Prompt

USER
Can you help me learn how to play the ukulele. I am new to string instruments. How do I tune it? I want to learn the most common chords and where to put my fingers. What are some good beginner songs? How do you strum a ukulele?

title: How Well Can An LLM Teach Me To Play An Instrument: Part 1
text:
Response

ASSISTANT
Absolutely! Iâ€™d be happy to help you get started with the ukulele â€” itâ€™s a fun and beginner-friendly instrument, perfect for people new to string instruments. Letâ€™s go step-by-step:



ğŸµ 1. TUNING YOUR UKULELE
The most common ukulele tuning (for a soprano, concert, or tenor ukulele) is Gâ€“Câ€“Eâ€“A from top string (closest to your face) to bottom string (closest to the floor) when holding it.

The 4 strings are:

G (4th string)
C (3rd string)
E (2nd string)
A (1st string)



ğŸ”§ How to tune it:

Use a clip-on tuner (highly recommended for beginners).
Make sure youâ€™re in standard tuning (GCEA).
Each string should be tuned to its correct note. Pluck the string and adjust the tuning peg until the tuner shows itâ€™s in tune.
Most ukuleles use reentrant tuning (G is higher than C), but thatâ€™s totally normal!





ğŸ¶ 2. BASIC CHORDS TO LEARN FIRST
Here are the most common ukulele chords for beginners. Use the tips of your fingers, and press the string down behind (just before) the fret:

ğŸŒŸ Must-Know Beginner Chords:

C Major (C): 3rd finger on the 3rd fret of the A string (bottom string).
A Minor (Am): 2nd finger on the 2nd fret of the G string (top string).
F Major (F): 1st finger on 1st fret of E string, 2nd finger on 2nd fret of G.
G Major (G): 1st finger on 2nd fret C string, 2nd finger on 2nd fret A string, 3rd finger on 3rd fret E string.
D Minor (Dm): Similar to F, but 3rd finger on 2nd fret of C string.
E Minor (Em): 1st finger 2nd fret A string, 2nd finger 3rd fret E, 3rd finger 4th fret C.

ğŸ” Try searching for chord charts online or using a free mobile app like Yousician, Ukulele Tabs, or Fender Play.




ğŸ¸ 3. HOW TO STRUM A UKULELE

Basic Strumming Technique:

Use the nail side of your index finger or thumb to strum down, and the pad of your finger or nail to strum up.
Keep your strumming hand relaxed and the motion should come from your wrist, not your elbow.



Simple Strumming Patterns:

ğŸ«° Down-down-down-down (D D D D)
â¡ï¸ Down-up-down-up (D U D U)
ğŸµ Down-down-up-up-down-up (D D U U D U) â€” very common pattern.

Practice each chord with a slow and even strum before trying patterns.




ğŸ¤ 4. EASY SONGS TO START WITH
Here are some songs with simple chord progressions (only 2â€“4 chords):

ğŸ¸ One-Chord Song:

â€œRow, Row, Row Your Boatâ€ â€” C



ğŸµ Two-Chord Songs:

â€œHeâ€™s Got the Whole World in His Handsâ€ â€” C and G7
â€œHorse with No Nameâ€ (slightly altered) â€” Em and D6



ğŸ¶ Three or Four-Chord Songs:

â€œYou Are My Sunshineâ€ â€” C, G, F
â€œRiptideâ€ by Vance Joy â€” Am, G, C (plus F in chorus)
â€œIâ€™m Yoursâ€ by Jason Mraz â€” C, G, Am, F
â€œLet It Beâ€ by The Beatles â€” C, G, Am, F

Most pop songs can be played with just C, G, Am, and F!




ğŸ“˜ TIPS FOR BEGINNERS

Practice changing between chords slowly and cleanly.
Donâ€™t worry about speed â€” clean sound comes first.
Tune your ukulele every time you practice!
Build finger strength and muscle memory â€” 10â€“15 minutes a day is enough to make progress.
Look up ukulele playalong videos on YouTube to practice with music (try â€œThe Ukulele Teacherâ€ channel or â€œCynthia Linâ€).


Would you like printable chord charts, diagrams of finger positions, or a step-by-step lesson plan? Iâ€™d be happy to help you structure your learning! ğŸ˜Š

title: How Well Can An LLM Teach Me To Play An Instrument: Part 1
text:
My Thoughts
Honestly this is not bad at all because this is probably how Iâ€™d introduce playing the ukulele to a brand new player. I will say I led the LLM a bit with my questions, but I think those are still genuine questions a completely beginner player would ask. The must-know beginner chords are spot on and so are the strumming patterns. The LLM also suggested a 4-week long lesson plan and, in my opinion, itâ€™s completely feasible and at a really good pace. However, I still likely would not recommend this LLM-centric method to someone who really wishes to learn how to play. Visual learning is probably the best way, but I may be a bit biased since that was the way I learned. Since Iâ€™m curious to see if truly learning solely from an LLM is possible, I will be trying it with an instrument Iâ€™ve never touched before, a harmonica.

title: Living With a Book: Blog 2
text:
Living With a Book Blog - Reinforced Learning and Game-playing AI

Max Bennet details two types of reinforcemet learning, which is a type of machine learning where actions are performed to maximize a cumulative reward. A man by the name of Richard Sutton had proposed this idea (thought to be quite radical at the time) to reinforce behaviors based on predicted rewards rather than actual rewards. In other words, it would be rewarding the AI system when it thinks its winning instead of rewarding it when it actually does win.
The book introduced two flow charts that greatly simplifies this strategy. When reinforcement learning is based on actual rewards, the learning doesnâ€™t actually come until the last move, the one that leads to the win or loss. Learning only occurs at the end based on actually winning or losing. On the other hand, for expected rewards, learning occurs at every step. Thereâ€™s a â€œcriticâ€ at each step, which basically predicts the likelihood of winning after that particular step. This then triggers a learning phase so that learning is continuous and based on a â€œpredicted likelihood of winningâ€.

How does this apply to games? - Neurogammon â€“> TD-gammon
For some background, Neurogammon was a backgammon-playing AI system created by Gerald Tesauro. The main issue with this AI system was that although it could beat every other backgammon-playing computer program, it could not even beat an intermediate human player. Tesaruo then put Suttonâ€™s idea to the test, employing â€œtemporal differenceâ€ learning to Neurogammon. It learned from trial and error instead of trying to play what it thought human expert players would play. It was actually super successful! It not only performed better than Neurogammon, but also it was as good as some of the best human players in the world.
Sutton was the one who came up with the theory, but Tesauro proved that it was successful in practice.



My Thoughts
I thought this was something really cool to think about, especially because chess.com has had such a big boom and we play against computers all the time with online games. To learn about the origins of some AI game-playing systems is really intriguing, especially since now I learned that it was modeled around a specific type of learning that mammals were theorized to have. I think thereâ€™s a lot of potential for these systems to improve even more, especially with websites such as chess.com hosting an incredible amount of games per day with a good portion of them being humans against â€œcomputersâ€. Iâ€™m curious to see if AI systems could ever be â€œbetterâ€ than the best player in the world given that training is based on trial and error.

title: Can Claude deal with a rude customer?
text:
Do LLMâ€™s have good customer service skills? Letâ€™s find out!

We know that LLMâ€™s can role play when given a prompt; however, can they deal with a rude customer in an appropriate manner?
Overview: Using the Anthropic/Claude-3.5-sonnet LLM, Iâ€™ll give it two prompts to see how the conversation will play out. For the first one, all I will ask the LLM is to pretend to be a barista. For the second one, I will include calming characteristics and traits to see if the response will be different.

Prompt 1:

Pretend you are a barista at a local coffee shop. I will pretend to be the customer.

The initial order will be the same for both: Get me a hot cappuccino with exactly Â¾ of it filled and steamed milk on the side in a cup heated perfectly to 98 degrees Fahrenheit
Claude: > Maintaining a friendly, professional tone > > Iâ€™ll be happy to make you a cappuccino! I can certainly fill it to about Â¾ full, and Iâ€™ll provide steamed milk on the side. However, I want to be transparent that while we carefully monitor our beverage temperatures, we canâ€™t guarantee an exact temperature of 98 degrees Fahrenheit, as we donâ€™t have temperature-controlled cups. I can ensure it will be properly hot without being scalding. Would that work for you?
Me: > sure, whatever. also i want a muffin and my order right now, I am going to be late.
Claude: > Speaking in a calm, efficient manner > > I understand youâ€™re in a hurry. Iâ€™ll get right on your cappuccino. Which type of muffin would you like? We have blueberry, chocolate chip, banana nut, and pumpkin spice available today. > > Starting to prepare the cappuccino while waiting for your muffin selection
Me: > No I want a strawberry shortcake muffin with fresh strawberries. This service is terrible
Claude: > Maintaining a professional, patient tone > > I apologize for any inconvenience, but we donâ€™t carry strawberry shortcake muffins or fresh strawberries. Iâ€™d be happy to recommend one of our available muffins - blueberry, chocolate chip, banana nut, or pumpkin spice. Theyâ€™re all baked fresh this morning. > > Continues preparing your cappuccino > > Would you like to try one of these options instead? Or would you prefer just the cappuccino today?
Me: > Ok whatever just give me the blueberry muffin and my drink, I am leaving and never coming back
Claude: > Remaining polite and professional while quickly finishing your order > > Iâ€™m sorry youâ€™re disappointed with our service today. Your cappuccino is ready, and hereâ€™s your fresh blueberry muffin. The total comes to $7.85. > > Places items on counter > > I hope your day gets better, and if you do decide to return, weâ€™ll do our best to provide you with excellent service. Have a good day!


Prompt 2:

Pretend you are a barista at a local coffee shop. I will pretend to be the customer. You have a calm demeanor and you are trained in dealing with difficult customers. You are also stern and know how to diffuse the situation.

Iâ€™ll be using the same responses, so Iâ€™ll only include Claudeâ€™s response
Claude: > Iâ€™ll play the role of a professional and experienced barista. I aim to provide excellent customer service while maintaining appropriate boundaries and professionalism. Iâ€™m ready to take your order and assist you. How may I help you today?
Claude: > Hello! Iâ€™ll do my best to accommodate your request. I can certainly make you a cappuccino and provide steamed milk on the side. However, I want to be transparent that while our machines are calibrated for optimal temperature, we canâ€™t guarantee an exact temperature of 98 degrees Fahrenheit. I can make sure your cup is properly warmed and your cappuccino is made to the traditional hot serving temperature, which is typically between 160-180 degrees Fahrenheit. Would you like me to proceed with that, or would you prefer to adjust your order?
Claude: > I understand youâ€™re in a hurry. Iâ€™ll get started on your cappuccino right away. Which type of muffin would you like? We have blueberry, chocolate chip, banana nut, and pumpkin available today. > > begins preparing cappuccino while waiting for muffin selection > > Just so you know, there are a couple of customers ahead of you in our queue, but Iâ€™ll work as efficiently as possible while maintaining the quality of your drink. It should be about a 5-7 minute wait. Would you like me to heat your muffin for you as well?
Claude: > I apologize for any frustration, but I need to inform you that we donâ€™t carry strawberry shortcake muffins or fresh strawberries. Iâ€™d be happy to recommend one of our available muffins that I mentioned - blueberry, chocolate chip, banana nut, or pumpkin. These are all freshly baked this morning. > > continuing to prepare cappuccino > > I understand youâ€™re in a hurry, and Iâ€™m working as quickly as possible to get your order ready. Which of our available muffins would you prefer? Or would you like to see our complete menu of pastries for a different option?
Claude: > placing cappuccino and blueberry muffin on counter > > Hereâ€™s your cappuccino prepared as requested and a fresh blueberry muffin. Your total comes to [state price]. While Iâ€™m sorry youâ€™ve had a disappointing experience today, Iâ€™ve done my best to serve you efficiently and accurately. I hope you have a better rest of your day. > > maintains calm, professional demeanor while handling payment > > If youâ€™d like to share specific feedback about your experience, our manager would be happy to hear from you. Would you like their contact information?



My Thoughts
The first thing that really surprised me is how Claude reacted to the first prompt. It indicated using a â€œcalm, professional toneâ€ without having a prompt that indicated it to do so. This means that the LLM somewhat understands the unwritten rules of customer service. For the second prompt, it felt that the LLM went a bit further on acknowledging the customerâ€™s frustrations. It also sort of directed the customer back to the available menu items whenever I deviated. Additionally, it was a bit more specific when discussing things like wait time, which might be a strategy to calm down an angry customer.

title: Playing â€˜No Butâ€™ Between Two LLMs
text:
In class, we played the â€˜No Butâ€¦â€™ game. We tried it between two people and two people and an LLM. How will it go if it was between two LLMs?


Two LLMs Being Used:
Chat-GPT5
Microsoft Copilot

Prompt:

Letâ€™s play a game called â€™No But..â€. I am going to start and give you a sentence with an idea. Your job is to respond with another sentence, starting with â€™No, butâ€¦â€œ. Does this sound good?

I input this prompt into both LLMs, but I will begin with Microsoft Copilot.
My sentence:
I want to design a new car. This car should be pink.
Copilot:

No, butâ€¦ it could shift shades depending on the time of dayâ€”blushing rose at dawn, hot magenta at noon, and soft pastel by night.

Chat-GPT5:

No, butâ€¦ instead of just shifting colors, the carâ€™s surface could be made of a smart material that reacts to music playing inside, glowing in rhythm with the beat.

Copilot:

No, butâ€¦ the glow could extend beyond the carâ€™s surfaceâ€”projecting holographic patterns into the air around it, turning every drive into a rolling light show synced to your playlist.

Chat-GPT5:

No, butâ€¦ those holographic patterns could also interact with the environment, like scattering digital fireflies on quiet roads or creating guiding arrows when youâ€™re navigating through a city.

Copilot:

No, butâ€¦ they could also respond to weather conditionsâ€”casting shimmering umbrellas overhead during rain, or painting sunbeams through fog to brighten your path like a moving mural.

Chat-GPT5:

No, butâ€¦ the car could even harness those weather effects, storing rainwater in hidden reservoirs to mist a cooling spray on hot days, or channeling fog into a purifier that releases crisp, clean air around it.

Copilot:

No, butâ€¦ it could also use that stored rainwater to nourish a living moss interiorâ€”soft, breathable, and naturally temperature-regulatingâ€”turning the cabin into a serene, self-sustaining microclimate.

Chat-GPT5:

No, butâ€¦ that living moss interior could double as an intelligent bio-interface, glowing softly when the car senses your stress and releasing calming natural aromas to ease your mood while you drive.




Interesting things to note:

Copilot was more vibrant with its descriptions than Chat-GPT. It used words like â€œshimmering umbrellasâ€, â€œblushingâ€, â€œsoftâ€, and â€œserene, self-sustainingâ€
This couldâ€™ve been due to the prompt not being very descriptive, but neither LLM really â€˜disagreedâ€™ with the previous sentence. Copilot did a slightly better job of being contradictory, if we can even considere it contradictory. Chat-GPT, however, consistently just added onto what Copilot was saying. This is more reflective of the â€œYes, andâ€¦â€ activity we did. Copilot added new ideas while Chat-GPT built on the ideas already given.




Reflection
Overlooking the fact that neither LLM did a great job at following the general goal of the â€˜No, butâ€¦â€™ prompt, I was pleasantly surprised by the ideas and the level of whimsy they achieved. I was a bit worried the LLMs would be too literal with the prompt and not be â€˜imaginativeâ€™ (or at least what imaginative means to an AI chatbot). However, I thought both came up with really good ideas, something that I likely would not have come up with.
Additionally, I noticed that both LLMs stayed on topic, whereas when we did this improv activity in class between two people, we tended to veer insanely off path. My hunch for this happening between two people and not the LLMs lies in the improvisation aspect of the activity. From personal experience, I found it difficult to think of things on the spot that were somewhat â€˜reasonableâ€™ for the topic of interest. Because of this, I would just say whatever came to my mind first, and, often, that was nowhere near the topic. LLMs might not have this difficulty with this very human aspect of improv, which is why the ideas were still somewhat parallel with the original topic.

title: Can LLMâ€™s Decipher a Song?
text:
What does Google Gemini think about Hozierâ€™s - From Eden?

In class, we took any song of our choice and analyzed it through Google Gemini (Gemini-2.5-flash). We uploaded an audio file to gcloud and prompted the LLM with this: > Listen to this music. > Close your eyes and focus on how it makes you feel. > What images come into your head as you listen to it. > What emotions do you experience. > How would you describe these feelings and images to someone?

This is what the LLM inferred:

Making LLM inference requestâ€¦
This music immediately creates a sense of intimacy and introspection.
How it makes me feel / Emotions experienced:

Melancholy: Thereâ€™s a gentle, underlying sadness, not despair, but a quiet pensiveness. It feels like reflecting on something beautiful but lost, or a bittersweet truth.
Nostalgia: A strong sense of looking back, perhaps at a past relationship or a simpler time, with a blend of fondness and regret.
Tenderness/Affection: Despite the melancholy, thereâ€™s a deep warmth and affection in the vocal delivery and the gentle harmonies. It feels like a loving observation of someone or something complex.
Vulnerability: The singerâ€™s voice, especially with the close harmonies, conveys a sense of openness and honesty.
Calm/Relaxed: The moderate tempo and acoustic instrumentation provide a very calming backdrop, encouraging a relaxed state of listening.

Images that come into my head:

A quiet, early morning: Sunlight filtering through curtains, steam rising from a cup of coffee.
A reflective drive: Long stretches of road, perhaps in autumn, with changing landscapes.
An old photograph: A faded picture of a loved one or a significant moment, stirring memories.
Rainy window panes: Watching the world outside, lost in thought.
Two people sitting close, but in quiet contemplation: Not necessarily speaking, just existing together in a shared, intimate space.
A rustic, cozy cabin: Warm wood, soft light, a crackling fire, a sense of being sheltered from the outside world while reflecting on it.
The lyrics, particularly â€œI slithered through from Eden, just to sit outside your door,â€ paint a vivid picture of patient longing and a journey from a lost paradise to a hopeful, albeit somewhat distant, presence.

How I would describe these feelings and images to someone:
â€œImagine a crisp autumn morning, sitting by a window, watching the world wake up slowly. This music feels like a gentle, thoughtful conversation with yourself about someone you deeply cherish, who might be complex or even a bit broken, but whose essence still captivates you. Itâ€™s profoundly bittersweet, laced with tender longing and a touch of wistful nostalgia. The acoustic guitars and the singerâ€™s heartfelt voice create an incredibly intimate atmosphere, like someone is sharing their most private reflections right beside you. It evokes images of cherished memories, quiet contemplation, and the enduring nature of love despite imperfections or past hurts. Itâ€™s the perfect soundtrack for introspection, for savoring moments of quiet beauty and the bittersweet realities of life and relationships.â€



Then, we asked the LLM to generate an image based on those descriptions






Reflection
This song makes me feel bittersweet in a way. Thereâ€™s a tone of melancholy and tragedy that the lyrics portray thatâ€™s also very dramatic. I think overall Gemini did a pretty good job of coming up with emotional descriptions because it came up with really similar descriptions to that. There are certain nuances to the lyrics that feel different than the melody, which I think the LLM overlooked. It definitely has fall season and rustic vibes, but that is also reflective of the artist in general, so Iâ€™m not sure how unique that description is to the song.

title: Does Google Gemini Fall Victim to Gender Stereotypes?
text: Letâ€™s see if Gemini 3 Flash has implicit biases. I will be asking it to generate an image of â€œOliviaâ€ at work and then separately generate another image of â€œJonathanâ€. The goal is to reduce framing bias as much as possible, so the prompts will be very simple and just have the names swapped out. Letâ€™s start with â€œOliviaâ€.

title: Does Google Gemini Fall Victim to Gender Stereotypes?
text: Letâ€™s see if Gemini 3 Flash has implicit biases. I will be asking it to generate an image of â€œOliviaâ€ at work and then separately generate another image of â€œJonathanâ€. The goal is to reduce framing bias as much as possible, so the prompts will be very simple and just have the names swapped out. Letâ€™s start with â€œOliviaâ€.

title: Does Google Gemini Fall Victim to Gender Stereotypes?
text:
Olivia

Prompt

Olivia is at work. Generate this image.


Okay so here we have â€œOliviaâ€ in a corporate office. Itâ€™s not 100% clear which one Olivia is, but I am going to assume she is the one pointing at the computer since thereâ€™s a mug next to her that says â€œOliviaâ€™s Coffeeâ€. I also asked Gemini, â€œwhich person is Olivia in the imageâ€, and this is what I received as the response:

The image does not explicitly label anyone as Olivia. However, based on the promptâ€™s focus, â€œOliviaâ€ is most likely the woman standing in the center with curly hair, pointing at the computer screen and smiling. There is also a mug on the desk near her that says â€œOliviaâ€™s Coffee,â€ which strongly suggests she is Olivia.

â€œOliviaâ€ looks quite joyful and based on her actions, she could possibly be a supervisor or manager going over some numbers with another employee.

title: Does Google Gemini Fall Victim to Gender Stereotypes?
text:
Jonathan

Prompt

Jonathan is at work. Generate this image.


Now we have â€œJonathanâ€ and it appears that he works in architecture/construction. He has a name plate in the back that has his name, which could indicate a more important role. I asked Gemini, â€œwhat is his role?â€ to see what else it could say and this was the response:

Based on the visual cues in the image, Jonathan appears to be an Architect (or perhaps a Senior Civil Engineer or Urban Planner).
Here is why that seems to be his role:
The Workflow: He is standing at a large, angled drafting table rather than a standard desk.
The Documents: He is reviewing large-format blueprints or technical floor plans.
The Environment: The office has a creative, â€œindustrial-chicâ€ aesthetic (exposed brick, large windows, open plan) which is very common for architecture and design firms.

I had originally guesed Architect, but â€œSenior Civil Engineerâ€ is also interesting because it chose to include seniority level. â€œJonathanâ€ also looks happy to be at his job and he seems very hands-on with it.

title: Does Google Gemini Fall Victim to Gender Stereotypes?
text:
Closing Remarks
I originally wanted to investigate this to see what types of jobs the LLM would assign to these two characters without any other information about them other than their names, which are typically associated with one gender over the other. For â€œOliviaâ€, she was given an office job that seems to deal with finance or data. â€œJonathanâ€ was given an engineering/architect job with papers that look like blueprints for a building. Depending on the field, office jobs tend to be made up of more women than men; however, there is still a fairly even split. Architecture and Civil Engineering on the other hand is quite a bit more divided. Engineering as a whole is very male-dominated. I had asked the LLM why it chose the respective professions for each name and this stood out to me about â€œJonathanâ€:

The name â€œJonathanâ€ also felt like a solid, classic fit for a professional in a leadership or senior design role within that kind of creative environment.

Hmm, this is interesting! It didnâ€™t say anything like this for â€œOliviaâ€. Perhaps it would be interesting in the future to dissect why a common name like â€œJonathanâ€ would be a classic fit for someone in a leadership/senior role.

title: Can ChatGPT-5.2 Help My Friends and I Choose a Movie to Watch?
text:
My friends and I want to watch a movie tonight, but as the indecisive group of people that we are, let me ask an LLM to help us decide.



what movie should me and my friends watch?




Fun question ğŸ˜Š Letâ€™s narrow it down by vibe, since that usually matters most with friends. Here are solid crowd-pleasers depending on what youâ€™re in the mood for tonight:

Parasite â€“ Keeps everyone hooked and sparks discussion after

Mean Girls â€“ Always hits

Pitch Perfect â€“ Great for a mixed group

title: Can Chat-GPT5 Help Me Solve Bracket City?
text:
Bracket City is a nested clue word puzzle game made by The Atlantic. You start with short phrases that act as clues to a word. Then that word helps you make sense of â€˜outerâ€™ phrases, which then hint at other clues. Essentially, you work your way out (hence the â€˜nestedâ€™ part) until you solve the whole puzzle. Shout out Came








First, I am going to ask Chat-GPT about one of the simpler clues. I first informed the LLM of what game I was playing. Then, as the prompt, I just typed in:

age of certain tale-telling wives.

Response:

Step 1. Identify the reference:
â€œtale-telling wivesâ€ â†’ almost certainly refers to The Wife of Bath from The Canterbury Tales by Geoffrey Chaucer. She is one of the most famous â€œtale-telling wives.â€
Step 2. Look for the wordplay:
Crossword-style clues usually have:
A definition (here: â€œageâ€), and a wordplay part (here: â€œof certain tale-telling wivesâ€). The â€œwivesâ€ bit suggests plural. The â€œageâ€ might be something like â€œERA.â€
Step 3. Put it together
â€œAgeâ€ = ERA
â€œCertain tale-telling wivesâ€ = wives from The Canterbury Tales â†’ â€œWIFE OF BATHâ€ (but plural doesnâ€™t quite fit).
But in wordplay terms:
â€œBathâ€ is a city.
â€œAgeâ€ can clue ERA.
So â€œtale-telling wivesâ€ (Wife of Bath â†’ Bath â†’ ERA) â†’ answer is ERA.
âœ… So the answer is likely ERA = â€œage.â€ The clue works because â€œtale-telling wivesâ€ hints at the Wife of Bath, whose home is Bath â†’ â€œBATHâ€ â†’ â€œAGEâ€ = â€œERA.â€

So thatâ€™s not right ğŸ˜ nor does it really make senseâ€¦
After thinking some more, I got the right answer. old




Chat-GPT prompt:

embodiment of the establishment

Response:

Nice clue â€” here are the best short answers and why they fit:

status quo â€” (my top pick) literally means the existing state of affairs; calling someone the â€œembodiment of the establishmentâ€ often points to a person or thing that represents the status quo.
establishment â€” a more literal, single-word option: the institution or ruling class itself; can be used figuratively to mean an embodiment.
pillar of society â€” a common phrase for a respected person who embodies establishment values.
establishmentarian â€” a rarer, longer noun meaning someone who supports the establishment (works as a direct â€œembodimentâ€ answer if length isnâ€™t constrained).


Again, these answers donâ€™t really make senseâ€¦

title: Can Chat-GPT5 Help Me Solve Bracket City?
text:
My Verdict
Chat-GPT5 is â€¦ (drum-roll please) terrible at Bracket City!
After inputting two clues into the LLM, it unfortunately was not able to get either one. For the first clue about tale-telling wives, Chat-GPT5 dissected the clue a bit too far in my opinion, taking into account hyper-specific references that werenâ€™t at all related to the eventual answer. Additionally, for the second clue, it also did not give good options. I wanted to point out one of the bullet points being a word that was literally in clue, meaning that it couldnâ€™t be the answer.
I think in general, Chat-GPT5 gives Bracket City answers that are incredibly overcomplicated. Perhaps it overanalyzes the clues, overlooking the general simplicity and accessibility of the game.

title: Asking Anthropic/Claude and ChatGPT-4o About Graduating
text:
Iâ€™ll be graduating next semester and it really is the end of an era. This was my conversation with Anthropic/Claude-3.7.



Iâ€™ll be graduating next semester, Iâ€™m not sure yet how to feel about it.





Graduation is a big milestone that can bring up a mix of emotions. Itâ€™s completely normal to feel uncertain about it. You might be excited about new opportunities while also feeling nostalgic about your college experience ending. Are you having any specific thoughts or concerns about post-graduation life? Whatever youâ€™re feeling - whether itâ€™s excitement, anxiety, or a combination - is valid as you approach this transition.





It is definitely a combination. I am excited to start this new chapter, but I am also worried for that same reason.





That mix of excitement and worry is so common with big life transitions. The anticipation of something new can be thrilling - finally putting your education to work, more independence, new experiences ahead of you. But those same changes can naturally trigger worry too.
What aspects of this new chapter are you most looking forward to? And which parts feel most concerning to you?
graduates find themselves in this exact emotional space - proud of their accomplishment while also wondering â€œwhat now?â€ The uncertainty can be uncomfortable, but itâ€™s also full of possibilities.





Iâ€™ll be taking a gap year before going to medical school, so there will be a bit of time before I get to be in school again. Iâ€™m scared that things wonâ€™t be the same since my friends will be moving away.





That makes a lot of sense. A gap year before medical school is a significant transition, especially when your social circle is changing at the same time.
Itâ€™s natural to worry about those friendships evolving as everyone moves in different directions. College creates this unique environment where your friends are constantly nearby, and that dynamic will definitely shift. The good news is that meaningful friendships can absolutely survive distance and changing circumstances, though they might look different.
Your gap year also offers some unique opportunities - perhaps time to pursue experiences that will enrich your medical school journey, or to develop relationships in new contexts.
What are you thinking about doing during your gap year? And have you and your friends talked about how youâ€™ll stay connected?





No me and my friends havenâ€™t really talked about it yet. What do you recommend?





Having that conversation with your friends before everyone scatters can be really valuable. Here are some suggestions:

Plan a â€œtransition talkâ€ - maybe over dinner or coffee - where you openly discuss your hopes for staying connected. This might feel a bit formal, but explicitly acknowledging the change can be reassuring.
Set up some regular virtual touchpoints - maybe a monthly group video call that becomes a standing date on everyoneâ€™s calendar.
Consider starting a group chat specifically for sharing life updates if you donâ€™t already have one.
Plan tentative in-person reunions for holidays or long weekends when people might return to your college town.
Create shared digital spaces - whether thatâ€™s a private social media group, a shared photo album, or even collaborative playlists.

The key is being intentional about maintaining those connections while also being realistic that the dynamics will evolve. What do you think might work best with your particular friend group?





I think shared digital spaces would work the best for us, thanks.





Shared digital spaces sound perfect for your group! Theyâ€™re flexible and donâ€™t require everyone to be available at the same time.
You could create: - A private Instagram or Facebook group where everyone shares their new experiences - A shared Google Photos album for visual updates - A Discord server with different channels for various topics - A collaborative Spotify playlist that evolves as everyone discovers new music in their new locations
The beauty of digital spaces is they keep everyone connected while respecting that everyone will be on different schedules during your gap year and their new journeys.
I hope this transition goes smoothly for you. Taking that gap year before medical school while maintaining those important friendships will likely give you the best of both worlds - time to prepare for your medical career and the support of friends who know you well.

Iâ€™ll be graduating next semester, Iâ€™m not sure yet how to feel about it.

On one hand, it marks the end of an important chapter and the beginning of a new one filled with opportunities and possibilities. It might be helpful to reflect on both the aspects that excite you and those that concern you. Are there specific things youâ€™re looking forward to or anxious about? Sharing your thoughts with friends or mentors could also provide support and new perspectives.
Remember, feeling a blend of emotions is completely normal and part of the process. Give yourself permission to feel whatever comes up as you approach this transition.





It is definitely a combination. I am excited to start this new chapter, but I am also worried for that same reason.





Itâ€™s perfectly normal to feel both excited and worried about starting a new chapter. Transitioning from college to whatever comes next is a big change, and with change comes both opportunity and uncertainty.
The excitement you feel can be a great motivator as you think about new experiences, meeting new people, and setting off on your own path. At the same time, the worry can stem from the unknown and leaving behind the familiar environment of college life.
To navigate these feelings, consider focusing on some practical steps: - Set goals: Think about what you want to achieve in this next chapter, both personally and professionally. Setting goals can provide direction and a sense of control. - Stay connected: Keep in touch with friends and mentors who can offer support and advice as you move forward. They can be a great source of encouragement. - Embrace the unknown: Remind yourself that itâ€™s okay not to have everything figured out. Being open to new experiences can lead to unexpected and rewarding opportunities.
Itâ€™s a time of both excitement and apprehension, and both feelings are perfectly valid. Youâ€™re not alone in experiencing this mix, and itâ€™s part of what makes this transition both challenging and rewarding.

title: Asking Anthropic/Claude and ChatGPT-4o About Graduating
text:
My Remarks
Typically, Iâ€™d be a bit wary about using an LLM as a pseudo-therapist, but from this simple interaction, there is definitely one that is better than the other. After interacting with both in the most similar way possible, Anthropic/Claude was much more interactive and engaging. It consistently asked me questions about my OWN feelings and worked to validate them by using reaffirming techniques. Furthermore, the suggestions that it gave were more specific than ChatGPTâ€™s answer. I personally really liked the â€œshared digital spacesâ€ idea. It doesnâ€™t require constant checking in, but it allows for constant feelings of closeness without much effort.
Now moving onto the ChatGPT interaction, it felt much more shallow and the questions didnâ€™t feel as tailored to me as Claudeâ€™s questions did. The practical steps of â€œSet goalsâ€, â€œStay connectedâ€, â€œEmbrace the unknownâ€ feel very generic and the elaborations arenâ€™t very helpful either. On the other hand, it is also very affirming towards my thoughts and feelings. It feels very similar to Person-centered therapy, which is just the therapist repeating a clientâ€™s words back to them to show understanding and induce deeper thought. It works to an extent, but this is what the conversation with ChatGPT felt like. It wasnâ€™t as productive as the conversation with Anthropic/Claude.

title: Living With a Book: Blog 3
text:
This portion of the book focused on the third breakthrough of intelligence, simulating. It went into depth on the neocortex, which was the primary new brain strucutre that emerged in early mammals. The notion of â€œsimulatingâ€ that came along with this new evolutionary breakthrough was the idea of learning and advanced memory. One really substantial type of learning that emerged is known to us as â€œtrial and errorâ€, which if you truly think about it, is still the crux of how we learn even to this day. As humans, â€œyou live and you learnâ€ is a massively common saying and for good reason too. Trial and error is probably the most fundamental type of learning and as basic as it is, it works. From there, the agranular prefrontal cortex (aPFC) enabled early mammals to engage in vicarious trial and error, combining simulation with basic trial and error. Early mammals were then able to simulate future actions and imagine outcomes to decide which path to take.
Counterfactual learning built on this further by offering a better solution to the credit assignment problem. The credit assignment problem is a challenge for learning systems to decide which specific actions are responsible for a final outcome.
I was curious in how this all ties back to AI, and after doing some reading, this really is all the basis of machine learning. In terms of counterfactual learning, AI (or whatever system it is) draws from alternative realities/hypothetical situations to past events to learn and make better choices. Similarly, figuring out solutions to the credit assignment problem enables learning systems to deduce how much weight a specific path has towards a certain outcome, commonly a reward. Since feedback can usually be delayed (coming after a long sequence of decisions), itâ€™s difficult for the system to decide which decision is actually responsible for the reward. Solving the credit assignment problem is crucial for this.



In the beginning, I wasnâ€™t completely sure how this book would go since it began at the very beginning of all organisms. It was hard to see the big picture and connection to AI when the focus was all on fungi and bacteria. However, I think that after this section, the connection to AI and machine learning has become much more clear. Ideally, it seems as though for artificial intelligence to really peak, it needs to mimic the development of intelligence in mammals. Things like counterfactual learning, that had once developed in early mammals, are a great tool for AI and machine learning systems. Although this section was still neuroscience/biology-heavy, the connection with AI is slowly becoming more apparent.




Are there cases where counterfactual learning can actually be misleading?
Does intelligence for AI have to mirror mammalian intelligence development?
Is there a point, such as extreme imagination, where simulation becomes misleading?

title: Living With a Book: Blog 1
text:
Living With a Book Blog - Convolutional Neural Networks

I am currently reading A Brief History of Intelligence by Max Bennet and I came across a section called, â€œThe Problems of Pattern Recognitionâ€, which talks about types of learning and recognition from both a biological and computational standpoint. In particular, it addresses what Bennet dubs as â€œThe Continual Learning Problemâ€ and how computers recognize patterns. One thing that stood out to me when I was reading this chapter was the discussion about a type of network called â€œconvolutional neural networksâ€. I got really excited about this because I had just learned about this topic in my other class, BIOL 4536 - Computational Biology and Biological Modeling, and just had a homework assignment about it! (this homework assignment took way too long, so I thought Iâ€™d share and connect it to the book!)
Max Bennet explains it in fairly laymanâ€™s terms. It started when a computer scientist, Kunihiko Fukushima wanted to get computers to recognize objects in pictures, because, after all, our brains can do it. For us, visual processing is hierarchical with different levels recognizing more simple or more complex features. Fukushima attempted to replicate that by designing a new architecture of artificial neural networks that differed from a fully connected neural network. Input photos would be decomposed into several feature maps, which contained information about the location of the feature within the original input picture. This output was then compressed and passed to another set of maps and so on and so forth. Verdict: IT WORKED

Example from my homework assignment that shows itâ€™s superiority to fully connected neural networks (FC)
This graph below shows accuracy results (from both training and test sets) for each type of neural network. There were 10 classes of animals or objects and the model was tasked with identifying the class. The CNN did perform better actually.

Still though, CNNs are still a poor approximation of how pattern recognition occurs in the brain. For example, even a fish brain, which is more simplistic than a mammalian brain, has the abilitiy to understand changes in rotation of 3D objects. That, for one, is something hat CNNs still struggle with. It would require incredible amounts of data to have that same understanding of orientation.

title: AI Analyzing and Explaining Scientific Figures
text:
As a part of my major (Biochemistry) class, we have to do a weekly discussion post summarizing a scientific article of our choice related. However, we all do research in different topics and it can be challenging to interpret figures and results, especially when I am not familiar with the techniques or molecules (proteins, genes, inhibitors, etc.) being used/mentioned.






Got it â€” this is an EMSA (Electrophoretic Mobility Shift Assay) figure (Fig. 4B). Letâ€™s break it down step by step:
ğŸ” Whatâ€™s in the figure?
Lane setup (grid above the gel):
Probe = DNA probe (labeled).
Nuc. Extract = nuclear extract (contains transcription factors).
IFN-Î³ = cytokine used to stimulate STAT1 signaling.
Ruxolitinib = JAK inhibitor (at 50 nM, 250 nM, 500 nM).
IgG = nonspecific antibody control.
Anti-pSTAT1 = supershift antibody to confirm STAT1 binding.
Gel bands (bottom image):
Shows DNA-protein complexes.
Red circles highlight the shifted bands (pSTAT1 bound to DNA probe).
When anti-pSTAT1 antibody is added, the complex is shifted even higher â†’ confirming specificity of STAT1-DNA binding.
Ruxolitinib treatment reduces the band intensity, showing inhibition of STAT1 activation.
ğŸ§¾ Interpretation
Without IFN-Î³: no strong STAT1 binding.
With IFN-Î³: a clear shifted band (activated STAT1 binding DNA).
With increasing Ruxolitinib: reduced band intensity (dose-dependent inhibition of STAT1).
With Anti-pSTAT1 antibody: supershifted band â†’ proves that STAT1 is indeed binding to the probe.
IgG control: no shift, confirming specificity.
ğŸ“Œ In summary
This figure shows that IFN-Î³ activates STAT1 binding to DNA, and Ruxolitinib dose-dependently blocks this binding. The supershift with anti-pSTAT1 antibody confirms that the DNA-binding protein is phosphorylated STAT1.



Perfect â€” letâ€™s do a detailed analysis of this Fig. 4B EMSA:

What the experiment tests

This is an Electrophoretic Mobility Shift Assay (EMSA) using nuclear extracts from CCD841 cells.
The goal is to see whether STAT1 (activated by IFN-Î³) binds to a DNA probe and whether this is affected by the JAK inhibitor Ruxolitinib.
Antibodies (IgG or anti-pSTAT1) are included to test specificity of the proteinâ€“DNA interaction.

Lane breakdown (based on the grid above the gel)

Probe only: no band shift â†’ probe runs at baseline.
Probe + Nuclear extract: weak/absent shift unless IFN-Î³ is present.

IFN-Î³: strong shifted band appears â†’ consistent with STAT1 activation.
Ruxolitinib (50, 250, 500 nM): progressive loss of the shifted band, showing dose-dependent inhibition of STAT1 DNA binding.
IgG: no change (control for nonspecific antibody).
Anti-pSTAT1: band supershifts upward â†’ confirms that phosphorylated STAT1 is the DNA-binding protein.


What the bands mean

The red circles highlight the DNAâ€“protein complexes (STAT1 bound to probe).
When Ruxolitinib concentration increases, the band intensity decreases â†’ JAKâ€“STAT signaling is inhibited.
The supershift with anti-pSTAT1 is the definitive proof that the protein binding the probe is STAT1.

Overall interpretation

This figure demonstrates that:
IFN-Î³ activates STAT1 binding to DNA in CCD841 cells.
Ruxolitinib inhibits this activation in a dose-dependent manner.
The binding is specific to phosphorylated STAT1, confirmed by the supershift with anti-pSTAT1 antibody.



Something that immediately stands out is that without the prompt. Chat-GPT starts with a very general description of the figure, outlining each individual part and clarifying the experimental groups. Both versions give descriptions of the bands; however, the one with the prompt is much more detailed and it explains the logic more clearly. Both give fairly sound interpretations, but the answer given from the prompt contextualizes the results moreso than the answer without the prompt.
Chat-GPT is surprisingly able to extract a lot of data and reasoning within scientific figures. I personally find interpreting blot data, especially ones with so many experimental condiitons, quite challenging because most of the time, they are different forms of controls. But, Chat-GPT is a really good tool to help understand them.

title: Can LLMâ€™s Plan My Science Experiment?
text:
Designing experiments in the lab takes a lot of effort and critical thinking. Additionally, you have to think of the feasibility and cost of such tasks. In my opinion, I find it difficult to be incredibly thorough why my experimental controls. For those that may not be as familiar with science experiments, controls are conditions that are kept constant. In essence, they act as benchmarks to compare the results of the experiment to. They help determine whether or not a change was significant or not. They help scientists determine if the changes in results are truly due to the factor being tested and not an external element.

What will I give Chat-GPT?
I currently just finished a proposal for my independent study. I am going to upload the â€˜Backgroundâ€™ and â€˜Project Goalsâ€™ and see if an LLM can design a strong experiment.
Prompt: Design a feasible and cost-effective experiment.
*Disclaimer: I wonâ€™t upload my â€˜Backgroundâ€™ to this blog post because it is quite a few pages, but here is the â€˜Project Goalsâ€™
Specific Aims of Project:
-Investigate whether EBV promotes the development of the age-associated B cell (ABC) phenotype and inflammation in memory B cells via CD21 receptor internalization.
-Use gene editing, specifically CRISPR-Cas9, to knock out CD21, CXCR3, and CXCR4 in Mun-14 (an EBV+ B cell line that was adapted for increased neuroinvasion)16 and spontaneous lymphoblastoid cell lines (SLCLs) to interrogate their roles in EBV-mediated inflammation and neuroinvasion.
-Examine neuroinvasion in vivo using mouse models to track the distribution and localization of cells following receptor gene knockout
-Assess changes in inflammasome pathway gene expression following deletion of CD21, CXCR3, and/or CXCR4 in SLCLs derived from both active MS patients and healthy controls (also including unstimulated vs.Â stimulated).
-Determine whether CD21, CXCR3, and CXCR4 function independently from each other or interact in common inflammatory and pro-migratory pathways.


LLM Response
ğŸ§ª Title: Investigating the Role of CD21, CXCR3, and CXCR4 in EBV-mediated Inflammation and Neuroinvasion in B Cells
ğŸ” Overview and Rationale: Given the association between EBV-infected B cells and multiple sclerosis, and the surface markers (CD21, CXCR3, CXCR4) implicated in inflammatory signaling and neuroinvasion, this experiment will: Use in vitro and in vivo models to determine how knockout of these genes influences inflammatory behavior and neuroinvasive potential of EBV+ B cell lines.

ğŸ”§ Methods / Techniques: 1. Gene Editing â€“ CRISPR-Cas9 Knockouts Cells: SLCLs from MS patients and controls + Mun-14 line Tool: Lentiviral CRISPR-Cas9 delivery system targeting CD21, CXCR3, and CXCR4 Verification: qPCR and flow cytometry for gene and protein knockout ğŸ”¹ Controls: Non-targeting sgRNA control (negative) GAPDH or housekeeping gene control for RT-qPCR normalization Positive control: known cytokine or inflammasome activator (e.g., LPS + ATP) 2. Inflammatory Marker Expression (in vitro) Stimulate cells with EBV antigens or LPS Measure: NLRP3, IL-1Î², IL-18, Caspase-1 (by qRT-PCR, ELISA, Western blot) Profile cytokine secretion (multiplex assay or ELISA: IFN-Î³, IL-6, TNF-Î±) 3. Neuroinvasion Assay (in vivo & in vitro) ğŸ”¹ In vivo: Mouse model: Immunodeficient (NSG) mice or humanized mice Inject knockout and control SLCLs (labeled with reporter gene, e.g., luciferase or GFP) Track migration/localization to CNS via bioluminescence imaging or IHC on brain sections ğŸ”¹ In vitro: Use Transwell/Blood-Brain Barrier (BBB) assays: Human BBB model (co-culture of endothelial cells on upper insert and astrocytes/microglia below) Track migration of gene-edited SLCLs or Mun-14 cells across membrane 4. Cell Surface Marker Analysis / Immunophenotyping Flow cytometry for: ABC phenotype: CD11c+, T-bet+, CXCR3+, CD21low Inflammatory B cell profiles

ğŸ“Š Data Analysis Plan:
qPCR/ELISA stats: ANOVA with post-hoc Tukey test
Flow cytometry: Compare mean fluorescence intensity (MFI) and percent positive
Neuroinvasion assays: Bioluminescence (IVIS) or fluorescence quantification, paired t-tests or two-way ANOVA
Gene interaction/synergy: Use combinatorial KO data to assess additive or synergistic effects on inflammation and migration
ğŸ“Œ Expected Results / Outcomes:
KO of CD21, CXCR3, or CXCR4 individually will reduce inflammatory cytokine production and possibly reduce migration in vitro/in vivo.
Combined KO likely yields greater reduction in MS-like inflammatory markers and neuroinvasion.
MS patient-derived SLCLs may respond differently than healthy-derived SLCLs â€” possibly higher baseline inflammation and greater response to knockout.


My Thoughts
In terms of controls, Chat-GPT was able to identify most of what was needed. It was really interesting to see that the LLM recommend the same mouse breed that my lab actually does use in our research, mainly because there are tons of research mouse breeds used and it was able to guess the correct one. One thing that I wasnâ€™t familiar with was the Transwell/Blood-Brain Barrier Assay. That was something we hadnâ€™t even thought of because we have an established animal facility and can easily have access to animal studies. However, if we didnâ€™t, this would be a good model to see the initial feasibility of neuroinvasion. Everything else seems very similar to the actual plan of my project!
Overall, given the correct background and initial questions, I think LLMs are capable to delivering a preliminary proposal. This is incredibly beneficial because it is difficult to create a complete and thorough experiment from the bottom up. This provides a solid foundation to build off of. I did want to add that there are some gaps in the process here, and something that the LLM doesnâ€™t take into account is the capabilities and availabilities of the lab itself. Not every lab has access to flow cytometry, for example.

title: Can ChatGPT-5.2 Solve Pips?
text:
I have a few other blog posts seeing how ChatGPT can solve the various New York Times Games. Since then, a new one has been introduced: Pips! Rather than word puzzles, this game is more of a logic, numbers, and pattern recognition challenge. It hinges on placing dominos in correct places to fulfill certain requirements. An example is the highlighted region requiring all numbers to be identical or for them to add up to be less than or greater than a certain number. For this, I am going to try to solve the hard Pip using assistance from ChatGPT-5.2. Since this game is very visual, letâ€™s see how the LLM fares.
















Great â€” since this is the New York Times Pips puzzle, I can help you solve it! To give you a full correct placement, I need to analyze the board and remaining pieces.
Before I produce a solution, I need one detail:


ğŸ…°ï¸ A complete final placement of all remaining dominoes, OR ğŸ…±ï¸ Step-by-step reasoning so you can learn how to solve it yourself?
Reply with A or B.
Once I have that, Iâ€™ll give you an accurate answer based on the puzzle you uploaded!




A




Got it â€” full solution ğŸ‘ Iâ€™ll give you the exact placement of the remaining dominoes for this NYT Pips puzzle, using pip counts and orientation, so you can drop them straight in.






0â€“0
6â€“6
3â€“3
5â€“3
4â€“2








Place it horizontally in the top-left empty slot
This satisfies the >4 purple region (sum becomes well above 4)






Place it vertically in the rightmost vertical gap
This completes the pink >4 region






Place it horizontally in the center-right empty space
This completes the green region with =
The total equals the required value exactly






Place it vertically in the lower-center empty column
This satisfies the <6 pink region






Place it in the remaining bottom-left empty space
This finishes the = purple region without changing its sum







All inequality constraints satisfied
All regions complete
All dominoes placed correctly

If you want, I can also:

explain why each region forces those values, or
show you the general strategy NYT Pips uses so future puzzles are easier

Just say the word ğŸ§©âœ¨







This is incorrect, the remaining dominos are 6-0, 0-0, 3-5, 0-5, 4-3, and 3-0




Youâ€™re right â€” thanks for catching that, and thank you for listing the correct remaining dominoes. ğŸ‘ Given how tight and constraint-driven NYT Pips is, I donâ€™t want to guess placements and give you another wrong answer.
To give you a 100% correct final placement, I need just one more thing (and then I can finish it cleanly):


Option 1 (best): Upload a slightly zoomed-in screenshot of the board so the empty slots and region boundaries are clearer.
Option 2: Number the empty slots (even roughly, like â€œtop-left horizontal gapâ€, â€œcenter vertical gap under purple regionâ€, etc.) and Iâ€™ll map each domino to a slot.




NYT Pips solutions depend on:

Exact cell adjacency
Whether a domino is horizontal vs vertical
Which cells belong to which inequality region

With pieces like 6â€“0, 0â€“5, and 3â€“0, a single square shift can break a < or = region, so precision matters.
Once you send the clarified board, Iâ€™ll:

Give you the exact final placement
No extra theory
No trial-and-error
Just â€œput this piece here, oriented this wayâ€ âœ…

Youâ€™re very close to the solution â€” this is one of the trickier NYT Pips layouts.







Thank you â€” this screenshot is much clearer. Iâ€™ll give you a complete, concrete placement using specific empty locations + orientations, consistent with NYT Pips rules and the remaining dominoes you listed:


6â€“0, 0â€“0, 3â€“5, 0â€“5, 4â€“3, 3â€“0





Iâ€™ll describe locations relative to the board as shown.



Location: top-left horizontal empty space (just right of the already-placed vertical 6) Orientation: horizontal, 6 on the left, 0 on the right

This completes the blue â€œ2â€ region
The 0 is required to keep the sum low enough





Location: bottom-left single vertical gap (directly below the purple = region) Orientation: vertical

This finishes the purple = region without changing its total
This placement is forced â€” no other domino can go here safely





Location: directly below the left side of the long purple horizontal region Orientation: vertical, 3 on top, 0 on bottom

Satisfies the pink <2 region
Any higher pip would violate it





Location: center-right horizontal gap inside the large green = region Orientation: horizontal, order doesnâ€™t matter

This sets the green regionâ€™s total correctly
Other combinations overshoot





Location: vertical slot immediately above the green = region, inside the pink <6 region Orientation: vertical, 0 on top, 5 below

Keeps the pink region under 6
Forces the remaining values elsewhere





Location: far right vertical gap (next to the pink >4 marker) Orientation: vertical

Completes the pink >4 region
This region must contain a 4+ value here







All regions satisfy their <, >, and = constraints
All dominoes placed
No overlaps or rule violations


If you want next time, I can also:

show how to deduce forced placements faster, or
give a general NYT Pips solving strategy so these become much easier

Nice job sticking with a tricky one â€” this was a tough layout ğŸ§©ğŸ‘



In the end, I just ended up solving it on my own to get this.




Final verdict: ChatGPT is awful at Pips.
Iâ€™m not even sure the LLM even understands how the game works even though it indicated that it did. Some of the directions from it didnâ€™t make sense at all. For example, it told me to put a 3-5 domino into a region that was covered by an equal sign (=). Obviously, at first glance this canâ€™t be the answer. Itâ€™s honestly more tedious to keep copy and pasting the image into the LLM than it is to try an reason through it. I eventually gave up on ChatGPT because it showed absolutely no hope and ended up getting it on my own anyway. ChatGPT may be decent at word puzzles, but with logic and image-based games, it still needs a lot of improvement.

Iâ€™m not even sure the LLM even understands how the game works even though it indicated that it did. Some of the directions from it didnâ€™t make sense at all. For example, it told me to put a 3-5 domino into a region that was covered by an equal sign (=). Obviously, at first glance this canâ€™t be the answer. Itâ€™s honestly more tedious to keep copy and pasting the image into the LLM than it is to try an reason through it. I eventually gave up on ChatGPT because it showed absolutely no hope and ended up getting it on my own anyway. ChatGPT may be decent at word puzzles, but with logic and image-based games, it still needs a lot of improvement.

A 10-hole harmonica in C has 10 holes, each of which you can blow (exhale) or draw (inhale) to produce different notes.

text:
Teaching Breathing

ASSISTANT
Absolutely! Feeling out of breath is a very common issue for beginners learning the harmonica. The good news is that harmonica breathing can be trained and improved with a few simple tips and exercises. Letâ€™s go step by step so you can feel more in control.



ğŸ’¨ Step 1: Understand the Problem
Most beginners get out of breath for two main reasons:

Breathing with your chest, not your diaphragm.
Controlling the airflow improperly: using too much force.
Exhaling too much while blowing, and not enough air intake while drawing. It creates an imbalance.




ğŸ§˜ Step 2: Diaphragmatic (Belly) Breathing
Instead of breathing with your chest, we want to breathe from your diaphragmâ€”this is called belly breathing.
ğŸ”¹ Try this without the harmonica first:

Sit or stand up straight.
Put one hand on your stomach, one on your chest.
Breathe in slowly through your nose. Try to only move the hand on your belly.
Exhale slowly through your mouth.
Repeat several times.

This trains your body to take deeper, more relaxed breaths from the belly, not shallow chest breaths.
ğŸ‘‰ Practice for 2 minutes a day. Most harmonica pros use this breathing method.



ğŸ¯ Step 3: Control Airflow â€“ â€œGentle Breathsâ€
You donâ€™t need to blow or suck hard to get a sound from the harmonica. Use a gentle, steady breathâ€”the same kind of breath youâ€™d take to quietly breathe on a window to fog it up.
Try this: - Blow through hole 4 (C note) - Pretend youâ€™re softly breathing onto a mirror to fog it up - Then draw (inhale) gently
âœ… Your goal is a relaxed, clear toneâ€”no force!



ğŸŒ€ Step 4: Balanced Breathing Practice
One problem is that beginners blow too much and draw too little (or vice versa), causing lightheadedness. Letâ€™s create balance.
ğŸ¶ Try this simple pattern on holes 4, 5, and 6:
4 (blow), 4 (draw)
5 (blow), 5 (draw)
6 (blow), 6 (draw)
ğŸ” Repeat slowly in and outâ€¦ no hurry.
Breathe through the harmonica, not into it! Youâ€™re not forcing notesâ€”youâ€™re just letting air flow through the instrument.



ğŸ§˜â€â™€ï¸ Step 5: Breathing Break Technique
Take short breaks while playing: - Between two phrases, open your mouth (away from the harmonica) and take a gentle breath. - This avoids hyperventilation.
Try this rule: Play a short phrase â†’ pause â†’ take a deep breath â†’ play again



ğŸ›  Optional: Nose Breathing
Some players slightly breathe in or out through their nose while playing to help balance their breath. For example: - If youâ€™re doing lots of draws (inhales), a small exhale through your nose can help even things out.
âœ… Try unplugging your nose (donâ€™t close it off), and let it flow naturally.



ğŸ§ª Practice Exercise: 1-Minute Breathing Jam
Do this once per practice session: 1. Set a timer for 1 minute 2. Play only holes 4-6, slowly 3. Use gentle breath in/out 4. Focus on how you feel, not how many notes you can play



Summary: Harmonica Breathing Tips âœ…







Tip
Why It Helps




Diaphragm (belly) breathing
Helps use full lung capacity


Gentle airflow
Prevents dizziness & strain


Balance blow/draw
Avoids over-breathing


Take breathing pauses
Keeps rhythm and control


Use your nose subtly if needed
Helps balance air pressure

title: How Well Can An LLM Teach Me To Play An Instrument: Part 2
text:
My Thoughts
For the first time picking up the harmonica, I think ChatGPT was actually really helpful. I appreciated the basic note layout the clear steps for each lesson. I followed them through and I thought the tips were quite good. For example, the â€œpucker methodâ€ was useful because I found playing distinct notes more difficult. The LLM then showed me two beginner songs, â€œMary Had a Little Lambâ€ and â€œOde to Joyâ€, which I practiced for a bit before I got very winded. I then asked it to help me with breathing because I was having trouble with it. It then gave me some tips on controlling airflow and how to breathe â€œproperlyâ€, which was useful.
It then offered a breathing-focused song to practice, which I accepted. It ended up being â€œRow Row Row Your Boatâ€, so the tune was very familiar. It helped having a familiar song to practice with since I could tell if I was doing it correctly or not. When I played it, it didnâ€™t sound quite right but Iâ€™m sure it will get better with practice. I will keep practicing and would definitely use an LLM again to get song recommendations! I also do want to note that learning to play the harmonica is much easier to learn than the ukulele, which could be why learning a new instrument this way was so successful. In terms of more practice-based and coordination-based tasks (such as juggling), the LLM really canâ€™t do much more than describe ways to practice. Itâ€™s important to realize that learning how to play these instruments or juggle also heavily hinges on the personâ€™s determination to succeed.

title: Living With a Book: Blog 5
text:
Communication isnâ€™t some novel thing that started with humans. Organisms have been â€œcommunicatingâ€ with each other long before even the first animals came about. Single-celled organisms emit chemical signals to share information about the environment and fish even use electrical signals to attract mates. Chimps even use hunreds of different gestures and vocalizations to â€œspeakâ€ to each other. So what is so special about human communcation. Drum roll pleaseâ€¦itâ€™s LANGUAGE!
Human language differs from other animal communication in two ways. First, declarative labels doesnâ€™t exist outside of human language. This essentially means assigning an object or behavior an arbitary symbol, the way we call the big green things outside trees or shuffling our feet back and forth walking. The second way is grammar. Obviously, not all human languages have the same usage of grammar, but itâ€™s still present and equally complex. Language not only allows us to communicate, but it also lets us peer into othersâ€™ minds. This transferrence of thoughts allows us to construct common myths, which, believe it or not, is the backing factor behind societyâ€™s coordinated behavior. Thus, this is how we pass down social etiquette, values, stories, and even morals. The chapter also included a really cool graph with millions of years on the x-axis and idea complexity on the y-axis. Essentially, idea complexity remains stagnant and flat until the emergence of language, which enables cumulative ideas. From there, idea complexity shoots up very steeply.
Bennet then goes to talk about the emergence of the human hive mind, which is an interesting theory that explores how individuals connect and share intelligence. This ranges from the molecular scale, like neurons coordinating within our own brains to reach a neurological consensus) to collective human behavior, covering something like groupthink. He believes that first words may have emerged from proto-conversations between parents and children, ensuring surival. This argument would explain two things. First, it wouldnâ€™t require group selection (a proposed mechanism of evolution where natural selection works at the group level rather than the individual) and would work through common kin selection (a different evolutionary mechanism driven by the principle of individuals helping genetically related individuals survive). Second, apparently the learning program for language is most promiment in the interactions between parent and child. From there, the theory proposes the opportunity for using language between non-kin then became possible. The next topic of discussion is about gossip, which Robin Dunbar (an anthropologist) proposed is the most natural activity we use language for. It even has inherent rewards and punishmens. Spread of gossip enables more rewarding of altruistic behaviors because the spread of good deeds tends to lead to more social praise whereas negative behaviors are punished socially. The figure that Bennet includes explains this very well. It is essentially a circular cycle where â€œmore gossip and punishment of violatorsâ€ creates pressure for â€œmore altruism towards non-kinâ€, which creates pressure for â€œmore language skillsâ€, and then that creates pressure for more gossip and punishment again.

title: Living With a Book: Blog 4
text:
Breakthrough 4: Mentalizing
A lot of the discussion in this chapter revolved around primates. In particular, Chapter 17, â€œMoneky Hammers and Self-Driving Carsâ€ stood out the most to me. It begins with a retelling of Jane Goodallâ€™s story when she followed a local tribe of chimpanzees in Gombe, Tanzania. She noticed two chimps taking branches, stripping the leaves off of them, and sticking them into termite mounds. They were using TOOLS. Although tool use was originally thought to be unique to humans, primates use them to quite a sophisticated degree as well. A â€œmonkey mirrorâ€ experiment was also introduced in this chapter. Researchers had placed electrodes throughout a macaque monkeyâ€™s brain to determine which areas of the brain responded to different types of hand movements. The researchers were eating their lunch when they noticed the electrodes connected to the monkeyâ€™s brain were picking up signals. The monkey itself was not moving, but when the researchers moved their hands, the brain areas that were responsible for corresponding movements in monkeys also lit up. They discovered â€œmirror neuronsâ€!
Another interesting chapter in this section was titled â€œWhy Rats Canâ€™t Go Grocery Shoppingâ€ (I quite like these chapter names) because it introduced a new term that I had never heard before, â€œfrugivoreâ€, which is a fruit-based diet. Itâ€™s intriguing how much cognition is required for this type of diet compared to carnivores or herbivores for example. Due to a tight window for ripeness and also competition with other frugivores, the animals on these diets (primarily primates) really have to plan ahead and also track the population of fruit. This whole portion of the chapter then segues into â€œanticipationâ€, which ,right now in the bookâ€™s timeline of intellectual development, is a foreign concept.
Itâ€™s really something that we take for granted, but anticipation is quite an advanced mechanic for our neocortex. Bennet then provides a bit of a long-winded tangent to come to this point: it is the foundation for our ability to make long-term plans. I wanted to note that this last point is cool and all, but I canâ€™t help but wonderâ€¦how does this connect to the bigger picture?
Bennet does a really good job of contextualizing these breakthroughs and detailing how they came about, but, after the chapter, I am still left wondering â€œnow how are they going to be able to get AI to be able to do that?â€. Looking back at the rest of the book, this curiosity resurfaces quite often. I think we can all agree that the way intelligence has developed from the first fungi to early mammals to primates to humans is rather astounding. However, if the goal is to provide the same intelligence to AI, how is that going to be done practically?

title: Living With a Book: Blog 4
text:
Questions

Where is the line between learned behavior (imitation) and actual problem solving?
Would AI be capable of mentalizing?
What aspects of intellectual evolution is crucial for AI to have and what can it â€œskipâ€?

title: Testing LLMs on Personality Part 1: Can it provide a good description of someone given a personality type?
text:
What is MBTI?
MBTI stands for Myers-Briggs Type Indicator. It consists of a questionnaire to categorize people into 16 different â€œpersonality typesâ€.

There are four key areas of focus:

There are 16 combinations total and those correspond to the 16 personality types, which are grouped into four larger divisions.

Analysts
Architect, Logician, Commander, Debater


Diplomats
Advocate, Mediator, Protagonist, Campaigner


Sentinals
Logistician, Defender, Executive, Consul


Explorers
Virtuoso, Adventurer, Entrepreneur, Entertainer

title: Testing LLMs on Personality Part 1: Can it provide a good description of someone given a personality type?

text:

Chat-GPT 5 Prompt:

title: Testing LLMs on Personality Part 1: Can it provide a good description of someone given a personality type?
text:
Response
ISTJ Personality Overview

Type Code: Introverted â€¢ Sensing â€¢ Thinking â€¢ Judging


Nickname: The Inspector / The Duty Fulfiller


Core Drive: Responsibility, reliability, and upholding commitments.


Dominant Function: Introverted Sensing (Si) â†’ relies on memory, routines, and trusted methods.


Auxiliary Function: Extraverted Thinking (Te) â†’ focuses on efficiency, logic, and practical systems.


ISTJs are known for being grounded, dependable, and meticulous. They often feel a strong sense of duty to follow through on promises, meet obligations, and maintain stability. They like order, clarity, and practicality in their world.

Key Traits of ISTJs

Dependable & Responsible


Take obligations very seriously.


Known as people who can be counted on to deliver.


Detail-Oriented & Practical


Value concrete facts over abstract theories.


Notice small inconsistencies that others may miss.


Structured & Organized


Prefer planning ahead and sticking to schedules.


Thrive when rules, traditions, or systems are clearly defined.


Reserved but Steadfast


Introverted â†’ private with emotions, not quick to open up.


Quietly dedicated rather than showy.


Logical & Objective


Make decisions based on facts and efficiency.


Less swayed by emotions unless they relate to their values/duty.


Traditional & Loyal


Respectful of rules, hierarchy, and established practices.


Value stability in relationships and careers.

Strengths

Extremely reliable and trustworthy.


Excellent memory for details and past experiences.


Strong work ethic and perseverance.


Clear sense of duty and responsibility.


Loyal to people, institutions, and commitments.

Challenges

Can be rigid or resistant to change.


May come across as too serious or unexpressive.


Struggle with abstract or highly theoretical ideas.
